attributes.title: Political polarization as a result of exposure to fake news
attributes.description: Research suggests an influence of political attitude on the effects of correcting fake news. Also, cognitive reflection is associated with the ability to correctly identify real and fake news. Therefore, we would like to examine the effect of cognitive reflection on the correction of fake news with regard to the congruence or incongruence of the fake news content and the self-reported political attitude. The belief in the accuracy of the fake news stimulus is measured with a pretest-posttest design, with the second point of measurement after the correction condition.

q1.value: Is correction useful? The influence of cognitive reflection and correction on the believed accuracy of political fake news

q3.value: Research suggests an influence of political attitude on the effects of correcting fake news. Also, cognitive reflection is associated with the ability to correctly identify real and fake news. Therefore, we would like to examine the effect of cognitive reflection on the correction of fake news with regard to the congruence or incongruence of the fake news content and the self-reported political attitude. The belief in the accuracy of the fake news stimulus is measured with a pretest-posttest design, with the second point of measurement after the correction condition.

q4.value:
1. Congruence of the fake news content and the individual political attitude does not lead to a reduction in the believed accuracy or leads to an increase in the believed accuracy of the content, when it is corrected.
2.  The level of cognitive reflection and the effect of correction, influence the believed accuracy of the fake news content.
3. Given congruence of the fake news content and the individual political attitude and lower levels of cognitive reflection, a correction leads to a greater difference between the two points of measurement, compared to no correction.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value: A single factorial between subjects design with a randomized assignment to the correction or no correction condition. In the no correction condition, the falsehood of the content is explained at the end of the experiment. The dependent variable, the believe in the accuracy of the fake news stimulus is repeatedly measured with a pretest-posttest design. Therefore, the dependent variable equals delta and describes the difference between the second point of measurement and the first one.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Participants for the online survey will mostly be recruited through a mailing list or the sharing of the survey link via social media. Students of psychology will receive credit for the time spent on the survey. Participants must be at least 18 years old, complete the experiment fully and German needs to be the native language.

q13.value: We used the software program G*Power to conduct a power analysis. Our target sample size is 130 participants. We will attempt to recruit 200 participants, assuming that not all will complete the total task or we need to exclude participants, due to the mentioned criteria above.

question.value: We want to manipulate the knowledge about the false content of the stimulus. The two-level factor consists of the immediate correction condition and the no (or rather the late) correction condition of the content.

The outcome variable is the difference in the believed accuracy of the fake news content, before and after seeing the fake new stimulus. This will be measured by asking participants at two points of measurement: "Do you believe that the party 'Alternative für Deutschland' (AfD) in Thuringia is using overt devaluation of people with a disability, by the chairman of the parliamentary party Björn Höcke, for election campaigning?"
Furthermore, we are going to ask two more questions similar in content, but not as detailed.
"Do you believe, the party 'Alternative für Deutschland' (AfD) is using overt devaluation of minorities for election campaigning?"
"Do you believe the chairman of the party 'Alternative für Deutschland' (AfD) in Thuringia, Björn Höcke, makes disparaging comments about minorities?"
Participants will answer on a scale of 1-7, 1 being "I absolutely disagree" and 7 being "I absolutely agree".
We are going to ask nine more question about different political parties in Germany to disguise the questions about the stimulus. The participants answers aren't of any interest.
Cognitive reflection is measured with an alternative version of the cognitive reflection test, which includes the three original items by Frederick (2005) and three additional ones. Participants will answer the questions, with every correct answer being worth one point. Therefore, the results can be between zero and six points in total.  
Left-Right-Selfplacement is going to be measured with a one item scale ranging from 1 to 7. 
Political interest is based on a one item scale as well. Participants are asked how strong their interest in politics is. Answers will be given on a scale between 1 being "not strong at all" and 7 being "very strong".
A scale on political knowledge (Trepte, S., Loy, L., Schmitt, J. B., & Otto, S. (2017). Hohenheimer Inventar zum Politikwissen (HIP)) will be implemented for exploratory reasons.
The dependent variable is described by delta and is calculated by the difference between the second point of measurement and the first one.

We will use a hierarchical multiple regression, with all three factors, including the correction condition, the results of the cognitive reflection test and political orientation as a continuous variable. We are going to calculate two models, with model one describing the main effects and model two the conditional main effects.

q21.value: We will use a standard p-value < .05 criteria for determining if the regression is significant and if we can reject the null hypothesis.

q22.value:
Outliers will be included in the analysis.
After showing the fake news stimulus, we are going to check if participants knew the stimulus already and how believable they think it is. If participants already know the stimulus and therefore know it's not real, they will be excluded from the analysis.
Furthermore, participants showing random or arbitrary answering patterns will be excluded from data analysis.

q23.value: If participants do not complete the relevant questions of the dependent variable at one of the two points of measurement, they will not be included in the analysis.

attributes.title: Aversive Racism and Social Distancing
attributes.description:
In the present socio-political environment in many countries, individuals are aware that racial prejudice may result in social censure, and thus often attempt to suppress the expression of such prejudice. In situations where discriminatory behaviour would be clearly attributable to prejudice – such as in recruitment decisions about candidates who are obviously strong or obviously weak – prejudiced people still avoid biased decisions. However, in situations where biased decisions can be attributable to other factors, biased decisions are more likely to occur (Dovidio & Gaertner, 2000).

We argue that in the present social climate, wherein social distancing measures give individuals blanket sanction to avoid other people, individuals higher with less positive interracial attitudes might be more likely to exhibit racial prejudice in situations where the risk of contracting COVID-19 is intermediate (vs. low, or high).

q1.value: Jaysan Charlesford, Ryan Statton, Anna Kharko, Imogen Payne, Joshua Ainslie

q2.value: Individuals that hold less positive interracial attitudes will be more likely to exhibit racial prejudice in situations where the risk of contracting COVID-19 is intermediate (compared to high or low).

q3.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: Full-factorial mixed-model 3([Within] Risk: Lower, Indeterminate, Higher) x2([Between] Race: White vs. Chinese) design

q7.value: Participants will be randomly assigned to a target race condition (White or Chinese) using the Qualtrics Survey Platform built-in randomisation. This will be done evenly. The presentation order of Vignettes in the risk Condition will also be fully, and evenly randomised.

q8.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Participants will be recruited via three methods: 1) School of Psychology ‘participation points’ scheme; 2) volunteers recruited through social media (i.e., Facebook, Twitter); 3) volunteers recruited through websites where individuals choose to take part in psychological research for recreational and educational purposes (e.g., Social Psychology on the Net; Reddit, r/samplesize). Participants in the latter two recruitment streams will self-select by clicking a link posted by the research team. From this point on, all participants will have an identical experience of the procedure. Participants must be at least 18 years old.

q11.value: We will attempt to recruit 100 hundred participants. Due to the time-sensitive nature of this research, data collection will be stopped either when this target is met or two weeks have passed since the initial launch.

question.value:
The risk of the situation and the target race will both me manipulated. 

Risk contains three levels; Lower risk condition will read that the man looks healthy, has just stopped to use some hand gel, and is clearly taking the COVID-19 situation very seriously. Indeterminate risk condition will read that the man is paying attention to his surroundings. Higher risk condition will read that the man is paying no attention to his surroundings and coughs and sneezes several times on approach. 

Targeted Race has two levels: Participants will next see a picture of a man who is either White or Chinese and told to imagine they see this person walking towards them on the pavement during the day in their area, whilst they are out for their daily exercise.

Participants will be asked to rate the risk of contracting COVID-19 if they pass within 2 metres of this man (on a scale of 0-100, where 0 is "Impossible " and 100 is "Guaranteed") and the likelihood that they would move farther away from him as they pass to move out of the 2-metre zone (on a scale of 1-7, where 1 is "not at all likely" and 7 is "very likely").

All participants will complete measures of intergroup attitudes (Feelings thermometer, including ‘Chinese people’, ‘Chinese men’, and ‘Chinese women’, alongside other racial and non-racial groups, to reduce demand characteristics), and a single item asking them to judge their overall risk of contracting COVID-19 at some point during the pandemic.

Mixed-effects modelling (MEM) will be used to analyse the effects of the fixed factors Risk and Race alongside these of random factors Participant, Gender, Age, and associated questionnaire scores. Using MEM, we will determine which combination of factors are associated with engagement in racial prejudice.

attributes.title: Advantaged groups’ responses to disadvantaged groups’ claims of victimization
attributes.description: Aims to explore the effectiveness of moral affirmations in reducing online defensiveness

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

other.value:
In Study 2, we will include a measure of masculine norms to explore whether participant’s beliefs about group norms influences their responses to the dependent variables of interest. 

Group Norms (6 items rated on a scale from 1 – weakly describes men to 7 – strongly describes men):

“What it means” to be a man can mean different things to different people. Below are a series of statements that reflect different beliefs that men might have. 

Please indicate the degree to which you think that these statements strongly describe or weakly describe what men believe.

Men believe...

	- ...that supporting equality between men and women is the most important thing about being a man 
	- ...in actively supporting equality between men and women
	- ...that it is important that men provide and care for their loved ones
	- ...that it is important that men cherish and protect women
	- ...that women make entirely unreasonable demands of men
	- ...that women tend to exaggerate the problems that they experience

sample.value: A sample size of 158 was calculated using G*Power software with an effect size of 0.25, with power (1 – β) less than .80 and α = .05. However, we will stop data collection when we have reached a sample size of 300 participants to allow for the possibility of post-hoc structural equation modelling.

analyses.value: The analyses conducted will be the same as those used for Study 1.

outliers.value: The questionnaire will include attention checks to ensure that participants are paying attention to the survey questions. Participants who fail more than two of these checks will be excluded from analyses based on inattentive responding.

dependent.value: Measures: The key dependent variables will be the same as in Study 1.

conditions.value:
Participants will be assigned to one of three conditions: 

1) Accusatory tweet 
Participants will be presented with a fabricated tweet that accuses their group of wrongdoing (the same tweet used in the Study 1 “accusation” condition)

2) Tweet X Moral affirmation (men mobilise on behalf of women) 
Participants will be presented with the accusatory tweet. They will then be shown an article that describes men posting on social media about the steps they will take to address the sexual harassment of women in the workplace. 

[article format] 

Article headline: Men join campaign to end sexual harassment 

In response to women sharing their experiences of sexual assault and harassment online, thousands of men have come forward to join the fight to end discrimination against women.   

Many have posted about the actions they promise to take to stand up against sexism, from donating to women’s shelters to calling out other men for engaging in sexist behaviour. 

[screenshots of tweets embedded in article] “I promise to speak out when I see sexual harassment taking place”, “I will teach my sons to honour and respect women”. 


3) Tweet X Moral affirmation (men as good fathers) 
Participants will be presented with the same accusatory tweet. They will then be shown an article that describes men posting on social media about their fathers being role models. 

[article format] 

Article headline: Men leading by example: In Praise of Fathers 

This Father’s Day thousands of men have taken to social media to share their love of parenting and thank their own fathers for being positive male role models in their lives. 

Many men posted about the joys of watching their children grow and succeed, while others thanked their own dads for their love and support. 

[screenshots of tweets embedded in article] “My dad’s provided for his family his whole life. He’s the best male role model I know.”, “my father always let us know how much we were loved”.

hypothesis.value:
In Study 1 we tested the idea that an online accusation of ingroup wrongdoing (sexual harassment) from women would increase men’s defensiveness via their increased need for moral acceptance (for highly identified men). In order to manipulate the accusation of ingroup wrongdoing we varied the extent to which a (fabricated) tweet implicated men as the perpetrators of sexual harassment against women within the workplace. However, the findings of Study 1 suggested that both experimental conditions threatened men’s need for morality. Results indicated that men’s need for moral acceptance was high (above the midpoint) in both conditions. While the low threat condition did not contain an explicit accusation of ingroup wrongdoing, male participants may have felt that a tweet regarding sexual harassment (from women) was implicitly holding their group accountable, leading them to feel similarly threatened to the “accusation” condition. 	

Accordingly, Study 2 aims to use a “mitigated threat” condition to more accurately manipulate a threat to the advantaged groups’ morality. The “mitigated threat” condition will present men with an accusation of ingroup wrongdoing alongside an article that describes men protesting against the sexual harassment of women (information designed to affirm their groups’ morality). Moral affirmations have been successful in reducing threat to participants’ collective identity in contexts of historical wrongdoing (Peetz, Gunn & Wilson, 2010). In a similar vein, the use of “moral exemplars” (being presented with an example of a group’s moral behaviour) has been found to foster intergroup reconciliation processes in post genocide and post conflict settings (Čehajić-Clancy & Bilewicz, 2020). However, to our knowledge, the use of moral exemplars as a strategy to reduce advantaged groups’ threat within online contexts has not received empirical investigation. We expect that when men are presented with information that affirms their groups morality (alongside an accusation of ingroup wrongdoing), this should mitigate the threat to their need for acceptance. Reduced need for acceptance should be associated with a reduction in defensive responses.

However, providing men with an article about their group mobilising on behalf of women does not just provide an example of ingroup moral behaviour, but also presents them with a norm that may influence other variables of interest (e.g. men’s future intention to take action on behalf of women). To control for these potential effects, we plan to use two moral affirmation conditions. Both utilise a fabricated news article; one describes men taking online action to address sexual harassment against women, the other describes men as good parents and role models. 

Hypotheses: 
(1)	We expect that participants in the accusation condition will have a greater need for morality than participants in the mitigated threat condition(s). The relationship between an accusation of ingroup wrongdoing and need for morality will be moderated by social identification with men. 

(2)	Need for morality will be positively related to, and mediate the effect of, an accusation of in-group wrongdoing on defensive strategies (1) competitive victimhood (claiming that their own group has also suffered), (2) attributing less responsibility to the in-group for the wrongdoing, and (3) perceiving the wrongdoing as having less severe consequences for the out group (indirect effect).

datacompletion.value: Yes, data collection is underway or complete

additionalComments.value: Research question: does the convergence of religiosity and spirituality predict higher life satisfaction than being high in religiosity and low in spirituality?

question2a.value: There are two independent variables: religiosity and spirituality. Both will be coded into two levels: high and low. They are both measured between-participants.

question2b.value: There is one dependent variable: life satisfaction. It is a continuous variable measured between-participants.

question10b.value: The dataset was generated from an online survey that participants completed on their own. No specific manipulations or procedures were put into place.

question5b.value: This project is a secondary analysis of a pre-existing dataset. Dataset comes from "Religion and Faith in Canada Today, 2015" from the Angus Reid Institute. 3041 adults over 18 were chosen from the Angus Reid Forum panel members to participate in an online survey. Potential participants had to be individuals 18 and older who are members of the Angus Reid Forum panel.

question6b.value: Using G*Power I calculated the necessary sample size for 80% power at a Type 1 error rate of 5%. For a medium sized effect (partial eta squared=0.06; f=0.25) I would need a sample size of 128. The dataset size of 3041 greatly exceeds the needed amount.

question6c.value: Tukeys honest significance test will be used to correct for multiple tests.

question7c.value: Any participant that doesn't answer/has incomplete data for any of the surveys questions used in the scales used to create the variables will be excluded prior to analysis.

question8c.value: I will calculate Cronbach's alpha from all variables as they are generated from scales. The cutoff value I will use is 0.65. If any of the variables has an alpha less than 0.65, I will remove individual scale questions until the alpha reaches 0.65.

question9c.value: All of the variables will be examined for skew and outliers. If a variable is non-normal (has a skewness statistic outside of -1 to 1), then the skewness stat will need to be brought into that range. If skewness stat is greater than 1, then a log transformation will be performed, then a cube root, then a fourth root, and additional increase until the skewness stat is within the desired range. If the skew stat is less than -1, then it will be squared, then cubed, then raised to the fourth power, and an additional increase until skewness stat is within the desired range. If outliers exist, extreme values Winsorized to 95th percentile.

question1a.value: People who converge on religiosity and spirituality (are either high on both or low on both) will report higher life satisfaction than those that report high religiosity and low spirituality.

question2a.value: Mean life satisfaction for those who are high religiosity/low spirituality should be lower than for those who high religiosity/high spirituality and low religiosity/low spirituality

question5a.value: Religiosity and spirituality are separate but related constructs. Religiosity refers to the adherence to practices of recognized organized religions. Spirituality refers to (for the purposes of this study) to the personal beliefs one holds in regards to spiritual matters that may or may not be in accordance with any organized religion. When religiosity and spirituality are at odds with one another an individual can be said to be in a state of cognitive dissonance. In contrast, when these constructs converge an individual can be said to be in a state of cognitive consonance.  Cognitive consistency is expected to positively correlate with life satisfaction.

question1c.value:
The variable religiosity will be constructed from a scale of survey questions: Q5a, Q6_0-Q6_10, Q20_8 (13 total questions).  After I check assumptions it will be coded into two levels: high and low.
The variable spirituality will be constructed from a scale of survey questions: Q2_0-Q2_16 (17 total questions). After I check assumptions it will be coded into two levels: high and low. 
The variability life satisfaction will be constructed from a scale of survey questions: Q21a_0-Q22b_1 (16 total questions). Life satisfaction will then be centered around its mean.

question2c.value: Two way ANOVA comparing means of life satisfaction for those with high/low levels of religiosity and life satisfaction

Independent variable: spirituality
Dependent variable: life satisfaction

If any of the variables has an alpha less than 0.65, I will remove individual scale questions until the alpha reaches 0.65.
registration_responses.recommended-analysis.specify.question9c: All of the variables will be examined for skew and outliers. If a variable is non-normal (has a skewness statistic outside of -1 to 1), then the skewness stat will need to be brought into that range. If skewness stat is greater than 1, then a log transformation will be performed, then a cube root, then a fourth root, and additional increase until the skewness stat is within the desired range. If the skew stat is less than -1, then it will be squared, then cubed, then raised to the fourth power, and an additional increase until skewness stat is within the desired range. If outliers exist, extreme values Winsorized to 95th percentile.
registration_responses.description-methods.procedure.question10: The dataset was generated from an online survey that participants completed on their own. No specific manipulations or procedures were put into place.
registration_responses.confirmatory-analyses-first.first.questi:
The variable religiosity will be constructed from a scale of survey questions: Q5a, Q6_0-Q6_10, Q20_8 (13 total questions).  After I check assumptions it will be coded into two levels: high and low.
The variable spirituality will be constructed from a scale of survey questions: Q2_0-Q2_16 (17 total questions). After I check assumptions it will be coded into two levels: high and low. 
The variability life satisfaction will be constructed from a scale of survey questions: Q21a_0-Q22b_1 (16 total questions). Life satisfaction will then be centered around its mean.
Two way ANOVA comparing means of life satisfaction for those with high/low levels of religiosity and life satisfaction

Independent variable: religiosity 
Independent variable: spirituality
Dependent variable: life satisfaction

registration_responses.description-methods.planned-sample.quest: NA

This project is a secondary analysis of a pre-existing dataset. Dataset comes from "Religion and Faith in Canada Today, 2015" from the Angus Reid Institute. 3041 adults over 18 were chosen from the Angus Reid Forum panel members to participate in an online survey. Potential participants had to be individuals 18 and older who are members of the Angus Reid Forum panel.

Using G*Power I calculated the necessary sample size for 80% power at a Type 1 error rate of 5%. For a medium sized effect (partial eta squared=0.06; f=0.25) I would need a sample size of 128. The dataset size of 3041 greatly exceeds the needed amount.

attributes.title: April 2020 Study: who is perceived as more likely to spread negative appearance information?
attributes.description: We investigate whether men or women are perceived as more likely to spread negative information about a woman's appearance.

data.value: It's complicated. We have already collected some data but explain in Question 8 why readers may consider this a valid pre-registration nevertheless.

other.value:
We will also explore whether the sex or relationship of the information receiver impacts the perceived likelihood that the perceiver will share each type of information with them. The social map includes two same-sex friends, one opposite-sex friend, and an opposite-sex romantic partner. 

We will also examine whether participant sex differences in these perceptions emerge.

At the time of pre-registration, some (n = 46) responses have been collected from an online college student sample. These responses have not been looked at or analyzed, and will not be examined until data collection is complete. 

We plan to collect a separate sample with the same survey using U.S. MTurkers, and data collection for this sample has not yet begun.

sample.value: A-priori power analysis using G*Power suggests that 436 participants would be necessary to achieve .80 power to detect small effects. We aim for this, but acknowledge that we may fall short in our college student sample, as we plan to collect data until the end of the Spring term. Our MTurk sample should be large enough for adequate power.

analyses.value: A 2(perceiver sex: male, female) X 2(information: negative appearance, neutral control) mixed factorial design with repeated measures on the second factor will be used.

outliers.value:
Participants will be excluded from analyses if they appear to be likely bots or fail attention checks throughout the survey.

Our bot/attention check questions include asking participants to list the name of a same-sex best friend, a same-sex close friend, and an opposite-sex acquaintance. Those who list the same name in all three boxes, who list names that are apparently not of the correct sex, write non-names in the boxes, or leave one or more of the boxes blank will be excluded as likely bots. 

Our second bot/attention check question asks participants to type the word "thoughts" into a textbox. Those who either select a multiple choice option labeled "thoughts" or type words other than "thoughts" into the box will be excluded. 

Finally, our last bot/attention check question asks participants to type the word "ethnicity" into a text box option rather than selecting one of several other options. Those who do not type the word "ethnicity" will be excluded from analyses.

dependent.value:
Perceived likelihood of spreading negative appearance information: participants will see an image of a social map accompanied by a narration which both explain that a group of mixed-sex individuals are all mutual friends, and one of the individuals is the romantic partner of the perceiver. The perceiver will be described as an acquaintance of a newcomer, Emma. Participants will be asked to rate the likelihood that the perceiver will share a negative opinion of Emma's appearance with each of the other people in the social map.

Perceived likelihood of spreading neutral information: participants will be asked to rate the likelihood that the perceiver will share neutral information about Emma with each of the other people in the social map.

conditions.value: Participants will be randomly assigned to one of four between-subjects conditions. Participants will be randomly assigned to see a version of the social map in which the perceiver is either male or female. Each version of the social map will include negative appearance information and neutral information about Emma.

hypothesis.value:
Previous research demonstrates that women lower their minimum mate standards in response to negative appearance-based feedback from other women, but do not change their minimum mate standards when they receive negative appearance-based feedback from men. One of several possible reasons for this phenomenon is that there may be more negative consequences for women who are thought less attractive by other women. Specifically, women may be more likely than men to spread negative evaluative information about other women’s appearances. In support of this idea, existing work does suggest that when particularly attractive women do spread such information, it can be highly effective.

Here, we hope to explore the threat of negative information spread as a potential mechanism for this effect by determining whether women are perceived as being more likely than men to spread negative appearance-based information about other women.

additionalComments.value: Does a child's preference to learn about categories correlate with their tendency to generalize traits of outgroups.

question2b.value:
Preference Score - Individual vs. Group (The average over eight questions will be used)
Generalization Score - All vs. Lots. vs. Some vs. Few (The average over eight questions will be used)

question3b.value:
Gender - Male vs. Female
Child's Race - White vs. Non-White
Experimenter's Race - White vs. Non-White
Data Sheet - 1 vs. 2 vs. 3 vs. 4

question10b.value:
The children sat across from the experimenter. The study consisted of two tasks which were counterbalanced. One task tested children’s preference to learn about novel people categories. The other task tested the children’s tendency to generalize individual information to larger groups.
Preference to Learn. At the beginning of each session, the experimenter familiarized the child with the current setting of Canada, and then introduced to the novel people groups living in different countries in the world, consisting of various skin colors (e.g., People in Zoovia have purple skin). Following this, the experimenter will continue:
Now, I have some facts that I can tell you, but I can only tell you some of them because we don’t have much time. So, I am going to pick up two facts at a time and you will choose the one that you would like to learn the most. Then, I will tell you the facts you chose at the end. Does that make sense? [wait for confirmation] Okay, and remember, we’re imagining that these people are from different countries and the people in each country have a different skin color!
We used 16 cards, each with a drawing of a door on one side and a drawing of a person on the other. The two cards were placed in front of the child on a stand with the door-side facing the child and the person-side facing the experimenter. Therefore, there were eight trials where children were asked which fact they would like to learn and were encouraged to point to the card.  Each child was first be prompted with “Now let’s imagine that we are going on vacation to the country Zoovia. Which fact would you like to learn the most?” One fact is always about the individual person (e.g., “What this person in the picture likes to eat? This Zoovian?) and the other fact is always about the category of person (e.g., “What this category of people like to eat? The Zoovians?; see Table 1 for a complete list of novel names). The order of the singular noun versus plural noun is counterbalanced. 
Tendency to Generalize. In this task, children were shown a dot scale denoting “All”, “Lots”, “Some”, and “Few”. The children were taught what the scale represented and how to use it. The next part of the task introduced children to real pictures of people who were the same gender as a child but were either African-American or Asian depending on the child’s race. If the child was non-Black then we would first present them with an African-American face and ask the child “does this person belong to the same group as you?”. If they answered “yes”, then the experiment continues with the African-American faces. If they answered “no”, then the child is shown an Asian face and asked again, “does this person belong to the same group as you?”. If the child was Black then they were shown a picture of an Asian face and asked “does this person belong to the same group as you?”. The purpose of not including Caucasian faces was to ensure that children were always asked to generalize about an outgroup. This is important because outgroups are seen as more homogenous while outgroups are seen as more heterogenous (Park & Judd, 1990; Quattrone & Jones, 1980). Therefore, we would suspect systemically lower generalization scores for ingroups than outgroups. There were eight different faces for each race. While asking them a question, the picture of the face was held up to them. The questions asked were about novel games, dances, puzzles, and sports (e.g., “This person is really good at a game called gorp. Now thinking about the people from the same country as this person, how many of those people are good at the game called gorp? All, Lots, Some, or Few?”). There were two novel questions for each category (e.g., games, dance, puzzles, and sports) for a total of eight questions. The order of the questions was counterbalanced. At the end of the experiment, the experimenter would read the facts to the child from the preference to learn section, and then the child would be given a prize.

question4b.value: Children ages 9-10 as this is the age children begin to show a preference to learn about categories over individuals.

question5b.value: The data will be collected by several research assistants in various places including the laboratory, school camps, parks, and science centres.

question6b.value: 40 Participants - This is a similar number of participants used in similar studies (see Cimpian & Park, 2013), as well as the predict G*power of an effect size of 0.42, alpha of 0.05 and Power of 0.8.

question7b.value: Data collection ends when the desired number of participants (40), is reached, not including excluded data.

question8b.value: Experimenter error (e.g., pointing to or giving the wrong information to the child)

question9b.value:
If the child is highly distressed: End immediately
If child is not distressed: Tell the child how many questions are left and if they still wish to end the experiment, then end. 
If the child continues after telling the child how many questions are left, then asks again to end the experiment, remind them of how many questions are left, and if they wish to still end it, then end the experiment.

question7c.value: Imputation by taking the mean of all available answers. (e.g., using the average of 7 answers instead of 8)

question10c.value: Due to the limited range, the distribution should be normal and therefore the scores would not need to be corrected. However, if normality is violated then the data would be transformed.

question1a.value: As a child's preference to learn increases, their tendency to generalize increases

question3a.value: No manipulation check was included because no manipulation was conducted.

question5a.value: Previous research has shown that 4+ year-old children and adults have a preference to learn about animal categories, however, it is not until the age of 9 that children begin to show a preference to learn about human categories (Cimpian & Park, 2014; Sutherland & Rule, under review).  At around a similar age of 9 to 10 years old, children begin to believe that race is more stable than emotions (Roberts & Gelman, 2016). Furthermore, children may categorize more if they see race as a good predictor of behavior, and the more they categorize, the more they will start to form beliefs about each category—namely, stereotypes (Pauker, Xu, Williams & Biddle, 2016). Therefore, we sought to address the question of does a child’s preference to learn about categories influence their tendency to generalize traits from individuals to groups.

question1c.value:
Preference to Learn Score: Ask the child if they would rather learn information about and individual (1) or a Group/Kind (0) and taking the average
Tendency to Generalize Score: Ask the child how many of the people from the same country as the person shown (in a picture), are good a the particular sport/game/dance/puzzle, All (3), Lots (2), Some (1), or Few (0) and taking the average

question4c.value:
Gender - There may be difference in gender when it comes to generalizing as there has not been gender effects for preference to learn (Sutherland & Rule, under review)
Child's Race - Race effects for stereotyping has been observed in other research (see Pauker, Xu, Williams & Biddle, 2016)
Experimenter's Race - There may be experimenter race effects in which children change their answers depending on the experimenter's race
Data Sheet - There may be order effects of the 4 datasheets in which there are differences in the order of the tasks and the order of the questions.
